metadata.title: Dehydration of fructose into 5-hydroxymethylfurfural in a biphasic system using EDTA as a temperature-responsive catalyst

S0926-860X(18)30521-0 10.1016/j.apcata.2018.10.023 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 The pH of the EDTA and water mixture (10 mg in 1.0 ml water). a: at room temperature, b: at 120 °C, c: at 160 °C. Condition: EDTA (7.3 mg, 0.025 mmol), PVP (100.0 mg), water 1.0 ml; e, f, g (at room temperature, 120 °C, 160 °C, without EDTA). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Color change of EDTA. (a) before reaction, (b) after reaction in the water system, (c) after reaction in the biphasic system (water:PVP/MIBK:2-But.). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 HPLC of the organic phase with the DMSO (a) or PVP (b) modified aqueous phase. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Temperature and time effects on fructose dehydration. Reaction conditions: fructose (90.0 mg, 0.500 mmol), EDTA (7.3 mg, 0.025 mmol), PVP (100.0 mg), solvent 5.0 mL (water/MIBK/2-butanol = 1.0:2.8:1.2, v/v). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Effects of catalyst loading on fructose dehydration. Reaction conditions: fructose (90.0 mg, 0.500 mmol), PVP (100.0 mg), solvent 5.0 mL (water/MIBK/2-But. = 1.0:2.8:1.2, v/v), reaction temperature 160 °C, reaction time 120 min. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Temperature-dependent solubility of EDTA. (a) before the reaction (at room temperature), (b) after the reaction (at 160 °C), (c) after the reaction (at room temperature). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Catalyst recyclability test. Reaction conditions: fructose (900.0 mg, 5.0 mmol), EDTA (73.0 mg, 0.25 mmol), PVP (1000.0 mg), solvent 50.0 mL (water/MIBK/2-But. = 1:2.8:1.2 v/v), reaction temperature 160 °C, reaction time 120 min. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The color change of EDTA during the process of catalyst reuse. (a) before reaction, (b) after the first run, (c) after the fifth reused, (d) after recrystallization. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Chemical structure analysis of EDTA. (a) FTIR, (b) TG. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Carbon balance of fructose dehydration to HMF under EDTA catalysis. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 The reaction mechanism of fructose dehydration catalyzed by EDTA. Fig. 11 Table 1 Fructose-to-HMF transformation over the EDTA catalyst a . Table 1 Ent. Dehydration of fructose into 5-hydroxymethylfurfural in a biphasic system using EDTA as a temperature-responsive catalyst Zhi Cao a b Ming Li a b c Yong Chen a b c Tao Shen a b Chenglun Tang a b Chenjie Zhu a b c ⁎ Hanjie Ying a b c ⁎ a College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, China College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing China b National Engineering Technique Research Center for Biotechnology, Nanjing, China National Engineering Technique Research Center for Biotechnology Nanjing China c Jiangsu National Synergetic Innovation Center for Advanced Bio-Manufacture, China Jiangsu National Synergetic Innovation Center for Advanced Bio-Manufacture China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, China. College of Biotechnology and Pharmaceutical Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing China Graphical abstract The widely available reagent ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) was used as a temperature-responsive catalyst to produce 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) from fructose. Using this catalyst, a remarkable HMF yield of 89 ± 3% was achieved in a water-MIBK biphasic system containing polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and 2-butanol. The pH of the reaction system based on EDTA as a catalyst was shown to be temperature-responsive. Moreover, the EDTA catalyst could be recycled simply by cooling the reaction liquid to room temperature due to its temperature-dependent solubility in water. A slight decrease in the yield of HMF (from 89 ± 3 to 81 ± 2%) was observed after EDTA repeated use for five cycles, and a yield of 88 ± 2% was achieved again after purification of the recycled EDTA via recrystallization with NaOH/HCl. The FTIR spectrum of recycled EDTA was almost the same as that of fresh catalyst, and TG analysis showed the decomposition temperature of EDTA is about 260 °C. Furthermore, a leaching test revealed that only 4.3 ± 0.2% of the initial EDTA was lost after five-time reuse. Keywords 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural Temperature-responsive Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) Fructose dehydration Biphasic system 1 Introduction Fossil fuels such as petroleum, coal, and natural gas provide a majority of the world’s energy today. Especially petroleum is not only used for energy supply, but also for the production of carbon-based chemicals [1]. However, the ever-growing demand for energy resources, the decline of petroleum resources, and increasing CO2 emissions are increasing the interest in the biomass utilization [2–5]. The transformation of carbohydrates into platform chemicals for the production of valuable fine chemicals, biofuels, and biomaterials is an important part of biomass utilization and has drawn the attention of researchers all over the world [6]. Among the sugar-based platform chemicals, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is a versatile one, and had has been listed in the “Top10 + 4″ chemicals by the US Department of Energy (DOE) in 2004 [7]. In general, HMF can be easily produced by mineral acid-catalyzed dehydration of fructose in water, polar organic, ionic liquid, as well as in biphasic systems [6–10]. In water, the process of sugar-to-HMF conversion always has a lower selectivity due to the side reactions of HMF, such as rehydration to levulinic acid and polymerization to humins [6,11]. In polar organic and ionic liquids, the side reactions can be efficiently suppressed and a desirable HMF yield can be achieved [12–16]. Nevertheless, the energy-intensive separation of HMF from these solvents is an obstruction of their commercial application [17]. In comparison, biphasic systems have been extensively studied since the produced HMF can be continuously extracted from the aqueous phase to the organic phase, which prevents HMF from decomposition or polymerization [6,8,17,18]. Various homogeneous acids, such as HCl. H2SO4 [8], AlCl3 [12], and CrCl3 [19] have been used for the preparation of HMF in biphasic systems. Homogeneous acids show moderate catalytic ability in sugar dehydration to produce HMF. However, their innate drawbacks such as equipment corrosion, environmental pollution, and lower selectivity, hinder the industrial application of these catalysts [17,20,21]. Instead of homogeneous acids, solid acids can be easily separated and recovered from the reaction system [21]. They are also less corrosive and therefore highly recommended as catalysts for HMF production [22,23]. Different solid acids, such as TiO2 [24], sulfated ZrO2 [25], zirconium phosphate [26], sulfonated carbon [27], Nb-doped tungstate [28], niobic acid [29], and the MOF catalyst [30], have been evaluated for the preparation of HMF in biphasic systems. High selectivity can be obtained using these acids, but they generally show lower activity than their homogeneous counterparts because they have a lower degree of active site exposure to reactants. In addition, the active sites of solid acids are prone to be deactivated due to leaching or humin deposition [31–33]. The less corrosive organic acids, such as formic acid [34], acetic acid [35], oxalic acid and citric acid [36], as well as p-toluene sulfonic acid [37–39], and trifluoroacetic acid [40] have also been used as a catalyst to produce HMF. A medium yield of HMF (50∼67%) can be achieved over these organic acids. However, these homogeneous organic acids are difficult to recycle from the reaction liquid. Furthermore, they cannot be used in the biphasic systems due to their high solubility both in the aqueous and the organic phase. Herein, we explored a widely available organic acid, ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), as the catalyst to produce HMF from fructose. We selected EDTA due to its temperature-responsive solubility in water. EDTA is insoluble in water at room temperature and became soluble at high temperatures. It is also insoluble in common organic solvents such as DMSO, DMF, MIBK, and THF even at temperatures up to 180 °C. According to the temperature-response capacity and the selective solubility of EDTA, a novel biphasic catalytic system was designed. In this study, we first showed the temperature-responsive properties of EDTA and the change in solution pH during the reaction. Then, the effect of the reaction medium, phase modifiers, reaction temperature and time, as well as fructose content and catalyst dosage were investigated to optimize the process. Furthermore, we also explored the recyclability of the catalyst and developed an effective method to restore the recycled catalyst. Finally, the chemical structure and leaching of EDTA were investigated to verify the stability and recycling capacity of the catalyst. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Fructose, EDTA, polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), and methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK) of analytical grade were purchased from Aladdin (Shanghai, China). HMF and fructose of chromatographic grade, used as standards for high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analysis, were obtained from Sigma (Shanghai, China). Other chemicals were of analytical grade and were used without further puriﬁcation. 2.2 Synthesis of 5-HMF The catalytic experiments were carried out in a 15-mL ﬂasks incubated in an oil-bath. In a typical experimental run, fructose (90.0 mg, 0.500 mmol), EDTA (7.3 mg, 0.025 mmol), PVP (100.0 mg), H2O (1.0 mL), MIBK (2.8 mL), 2-butanol (1.2 mL) were loaded into the ﬂask. After being sealed, the flask was put into the oil bath preheated to 160 °C. After magnetic stirring at 1000 rpm for 120 min, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and the organic layer was separated by extraction. The EDTA in the aqueous phase was recovered by filtration. 2.3 Analytical techniques Fructose and HMF in the aqueous or organic layer were determined by HPLC on an Agilent 1260 series instrument (Hewlett-Packard, USA) equipped with an RI 1260 refractive index detector and an Aminex HPX-87H® column (300 nm × 7.8 mm, catalog #125-0140; Bio-Rad, USA). The column was operated at 55 °C with 5 mM H2SO4 as the mobile phase at a flow rate of 0.6 mL/min. The fructose conversion (mol%) and HMF yield (mol%) were calculated as follows: Fructose conversion (mol%): (1) Conv ⋅ = ( 1 − moles of fructose residual in the water phase moles of fructose loaded in the reaction ) × 100 % HMF yield (mol%): (2) Yield = moles of HMF in product moles of fructose loaded in the reaction × 100 % The experimental results were analyzed using three parallel measurements. FTIR spectra (4000–500 cm−1) were recorded using KBr discs on a Nicolet IS5 IR spectrometer (Thermo-Fisher Scientific, USA). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The pH of the reaction system In the process of fructose dehydration over acid catalysts, the pH significantly influences the HMF yield and fructose conversion [11]. As a temperature-responsive property (discussed in detail in 3.4, catalyst recyclability), the changes of the dissolution state of EDTA influence the pH of the reaction system. Thus, it is essential to inspect the aqueous phase pH of this catalytic system. Since it is difficult to determine the pH of the complex reaction system directly under reaction conditions, we used the pH of EDTA-water mixture measured using a pH indicator under a designated temperature as a proxy. As shown in Fig. 1 , the pH value of the EDTA-water mixture decreased with the temperature increases, however, no observable changes of solution pH were detected in the control experiment. Thus, the changes of solution pH could be attributed to the dissolution and dissociation of EDTA, which increases along with the rising temperature. At room temperature, the pH value of the mixture is 3.84–4.14 (based on calculations) and 4.1 (detected by pH meter), indicating the determination of the pH with pH strips is not a very reliable way of measurement since the chromatic aberration and non-temperature compensation of pH indicator. However, the pH value of EDTA-water mixture decreased with the temperature increases could be safely concluded. 3.2 Dehydration of fructose in different solvent systems Many studies concentrated on dehydrating sugars in water due to its green properties, low rice, and high sugar solubility [11]. Thus, we first tested the fructose-to-HMF conversion in water under the catalysis of EDTA. As shown in Table 1 , in a blank experiment of fructose dehydration (entry 1, without EDTA), only 3 ± 0.4% yield of HMF and 32 ± 2% conversion of fructose were achieved. After adding EDTA (entry 2), the fructose conversion increased to 91 ± 3%, showing that the reaction of fructose dehydration can be significantly promoted by EDTA. However, the yield of HMF was still low (32 ± 2%), even though 91 ± 3% of the fructose was converted. This phenomenon can be explained by the fact that HMF agglutinates or cross-polymerizes with reactive intermediates at high temperatures to form humins or other insoluble polymers, visible as a dark brown solid at the end of the reaction (Fig. 2 b). This phenomenon has been reported to cause a decrease in the HMF yield and selectivity [24,41]. Conducting fructose dehydration in organic solvents is an efficient way to decrease HMF decomposition/rehydration/condensation [6]. Hence, we performed the fructose dehydration reaction in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethylacetamide (DMA), and γ-valerolactone (γ-VAL) due to their known capacity to suppress undesirable side-reactions [42–44]. However, the yield of HMF in these systems was comparatively low due to lower fructose conversion (Table 1, entry 3–6). The low solubility of EDTA in these polar organic solvents even at increased temperatures up to 180 °C seems to be the main reason for the low catalytic activity of EDTA in these solvents. On the other hand, the lower dielectric constants of these polar organic solvents than that of water (36∼49 vs 81) [45], may be another reason for the lower fructose conversion. By contrast, 32 ± 2% HMF was produced with 55 ± 3% fructose converted when the fructose dehydration was performed in DMSO. Here, the course of the fructose-to-HMF conversion could be facilitated by the acidic species released by DMSO at high temperatures, as has been reported in previous studies [46,47]. Another approach to minimize HMF agglutination or degradation is to carry out the fructose dehydration in a water-organic biphasic system. As shown in Table 1 (entries 7–10), the HMF yield showed a significant increase when the reaction was carried out in biphasic systems because the produced HMF could continuously be extracted from the H2O phase into the organic phase, suppressing side reactions [48]. A higher HMF yield of 67 ± 2% with a fructose conversion of 98 ± 1% was achieved in the H2O/MIBK (1/4, v/v) system (Table 1 entry 8). However, the poor partitioning of HMF into the organic phase left a considerable amount of HMF in the aqueous phase, which further polymerized to form humins. Phase modification could be used to further suppress the side reactions. In this work, we used DMSO, PVP, and 2-butanol as phase modifiers, since their outstanding performance in improvement HMF synthesis had already been reported [8]. When DMSO and PVP were used as aqueous-phase modifiers to suppress undesired side-reactions, the HMF yield was obviously increased (entry 11–15). However, while DMSO can improve the solubility of HMF in the aqueous phase [8], it can also partition into the organic phase which is difficult to remove in the subsequent purification process (Fig. S3a). By comparison, PVP is more suitable for aqueous phase modification due to its insolubility in MIBK (Fig. 3 b). The conversion of fructose continuously decreased from 96 ± 2% to 84 ± 3%, along with the increase of the PVP to H2O ratio from 1:40 to 1:5 (w/w). By contrast, the yield of HMF showed an increasing trend along with the increase of the PVP to H2O ratio from 1:40 to 1:10 (w/w), while a decrease was observed with further increase of the ratio to 1:5 (w/w), and a 78 ± 2% yield of HMF was obtained when the ratio of PVP to H2O was 1:10 (entries 12–15). As shown in entries 16–21, the fructose conversion did not exhibit much variation in the system comprising water:PVP (10:1, w/w) with MIBK containing 10–60% 2-butanol (v/v) as the extracting solvent, and a maximum HMF yield of 89 ± 3% was obtained at a 2-butanol content of 30% (v/v) in MIBK. At a low 2-butanol content (≤30%, v/v), the HMF yield increased with the increase of 2-butanol, since it promoted the partition of HMF. A further increase of the 2-butanol content led to a decrease of the HMF yield, likely because 2-butanol entered into the aqueous phase at the higher conetnration and thus hindered HMF partition into the organic phase and promoted the side reactions. These results led us to the conclusion that the biphasic system comprising water:PVP (10/1, w/w)/MIBK:2-butanol (7/3, v/v) is favorable for the EDTA-catalyzed conversion of fructose to HMF. At the end of the reaction, the EDTA showed little change in color compared to the water system, which also supports the idea that the biphasic system helps to reduce the formation and accumulation of humins during the reactions (Fig. 2c). 3.3 Dehydration of fructose under different conditions The effect of temperature and time on the fructose conversion and HMF yield were studied first. Experiments were conducted in the temperature range of 120–180 °C at 20 °C intervals. As shown in Fig. 4 , the fructose conversion was only 15 ± 1% and 48 ± 2% after reaction at 120 °C and 140 °C for 240 min. By contrast, almost complete conversion of fructose (>99%) could be achieved within 150 min when the temperature was increased to 160 °C, and further elevating the reaction temperature to 180 °C obviously shortened the reaction time to 60 min, which indicated that high temperatures are favorable for fructose conversion under the catalysis of EDTA. A maximum HMF yield of 89 ± 3% was obtained at 160 °C for 120 min, and an evident decline was observed after prolonging the reaction time or elevating the reaction temperature. The lower yield of HMF at the high temperatures or long reaction times may be ascribed to the promotion of unfavorable reactions, such as condensation or cross-polymerizations of HMF with reactive intermediates leading to the formation of insoluble humins [39]. Thus, 160 °C and 120 min were regarded as the optimal reaction temperature and time, which were used for subsequent experiments. The effect of the substrate concentration on the fructose conversion and HMF yield was inspected after the optimal temperature and time were identified. As presented in Table 2 , the highest HMF yield of 90 ± 2% was achieved at 0.25 mol/L of fructose. Increasing the fructose concentration further led to a lower HMF yield and fructose conversion, indicating that the higher fructose concentration weakens the ability of EDTA to catalyze the reaction. This phenomenon can be explained by the di-fructose-di-anhydrides formed by fructose at high concentrations, which contain reactive hydroxyl groups, resulting in a higher rate of cross-polymerization with reactive intermediates and HMF [41]. Nevertheless, 0.50 mol/L fructose resulted in a similar HMF yield (89 ± 3% vs 90 ± 2%) and selectivity (HMF yield/fructose conversion, 94 ± 1% vs 94 ± 1%) to that of 0.25 mol/L fructose. From an industrial point of view, it is of interest to work at a relatively high fructose concentration to reduce the cost of HMF separation and increase the space-time yield of HMF. Hence, we concluded that the optimal fructose concentration in the aqueous phase for the subsequent experimental design was 0.50 mol/L. The influence of the catalyst dosage on the fructose conversion and HMF yield was inspected by running the fructose dehydration reaction with different amounts of EDTA. As shown in Fig. 5 , the fructose conversion and HMF yield are obviously dependent on the catalyst dosage. Without EDTA addition, an HMF yield of 16 ± 1% and the fructose conversion of 42 ± 2% were achieved, showing the poor efficiency of fructose-to-HMF conversion under only thermal treatment in this biphasic system. By contrast, 50 ± 2% HMF was produced with 68 ± 3% fructose converted after 2 mol% EDTA was added. When the EDTA dosage was increased to 5 mol%, a sharp increase of the HMF yield (89 ± 3%) was observed, and the fructose conversion also significantly increased from 68 ± 3 to 95 ± 3%. A further increase of the EDTA dosage only resulted in a negligible increase of the HMF yield and fructose conversion. Thus, 5 mol% of EDTA was an efficient catalyst loading for the conversion of fructose into HMF. 3.4 Catalyst recyclability The catalytic stability over reuse cycles is a key factor in the practical application of catalysts. Since EDTA is insoluble in water at room temperature (Figs. 6 a and c) and becomes soluble at the reaction temperature (Fig. 6b), it is easy to recycle the EDTA catalyst due to its temperature-responsive properties. After each cycle, EDTA was recovered through filtration after cooling the reaction mixture to room temperature, washed with water and dried at 60 °C for 8 h, then used for the next run. As shown in Fig. 7 , the catalytic activity of the EDTA resulted in >90% fructose conversion and remained fairly constant even after reuse for five times, nevertheless, the yield of HMF suffered a slight decrease (from 89 ± 3–81 ± 2%). We assumed that the decline of EDTA catalytic performance can be attributed to the accumulation of humins. To verify this hypothesis, the recovered EDTA was dissolved in 20 ml of a 5 mM NaOH solution after the fifth run. The humins were removed by filtration and the EDTA catalyst subsequently recrystallized by adjusting the pH to 5∼6 with HCl (0.1 M). The recrystallized EDTA was reused after removal of excess HCl by washing with deionized water and kept at 60 °C overnight for drying. As shown in Fig. 7, the HMF yield was restored to 88 ± 2% after purification of the EDTA catalyst by recrystallization. The color change of the fresh, recycled (after the first run and fifth rounds of reuse), and recrystallized EDTA catalysts (Fig. 8 ) is also a strong indicator that the accumulation of humins is the main reason for the decline of HMF yield with repeated recycling. The chemical structure of the fresh and spent EDTA catalyst was also investigated by IR characterization. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the recycled EDTA (after purification) showed almost the same spectrum as the fresh sample, suggesting that EDTA still kept the original chemical structure even after five and ten rounds of recycling. In addition, the temperature of EDTA decomposition under air and N2 are about 260 °C (at 10 °C/min, Fig. 9b), suggesting that EDTA is rather stable under the reaction conditions. The high chemical stability of EDTA is the main reason for its exceptional reusability. The leached amount of EDTA was determined by weighing the recycled EDTA (after recrystallization), which showed that only 4.3 ± 0.2% of the initial amount was leached after five reaction cycles, indicating that the EDTA catalyst can be efficiently recycled. The excellent reusability can be attributed, on the other hand, to the temperature-responsive properties of the material. 3.5 Carbon balance A scheme of the carbon balance under the optimal reaction conditions is shown in Fig. 10 . In the reaction setup, 9.0 g of fructose (300 mmol C) was dehydrated using 0.73 g EDTA and 10.0 g PVP in the biphasic solvent system comprising H2O/MIBK/2-butanol (500 ml, water/MIBK/2-But. = 1:2.8:1.2, v/v). After the reaction, the organic- and aqueous phases were separated, after which the EDTA catalyst in the aqueous phase was recovered through filtration, and the MIBK and 2-butanol were recovered from the organic phase under a vacuum. The crude product containing HMF was recrystallized in water. After filtering out the water-insoluble matter using a 0.22-mm filter, the primary refined HMF product was recovered by freeze drying. As shown in Fig. 5, 4.67 g of refined HMF (222.38 mmol C) and 0.92 g of HMF oligomers (11.15 mmol C) were obtained from the organic phase. In the aqueous phase, 0.56 g unreacted fructose (18.67 mmol C) and 0.90 g HMF (42.86 mmol C) were detected. In the recycled EDTA, 0.06 g of humins (2.91 mmol C, based on the carbon content in the HMF oligomer) was identified. Thus, 297.97 mmol C was recovered and identified, and we attributed the rest of the carbon (2.03 mmol) to the unidentified matter in the aqueous phase. The total HMF yield was about 88 mol%, which was 20∼35% higher compared to the reported HMF yields obtained using conventional organic acids [34–40]. 3.6 Reaction mechanism Two general mechanistic pathways are recognized in sugar dehydration-the acyclic and cyclic routes [6,49]. Here, the dehydration of fructose to HMF is considered to proceed via cyclic pathways, since EDTA showed an extremely weak catalytic activity on glucose (HMF yield < 5%). Based on our results and previous reports, a plausible reaction mechanism of fructose dehydration under EDTA catalysis was proposed as depicted in Fig. 11 . At high temperatures, EDTA dissolves into the water and the hydrogen ions (H+), which are believed to be responsible for the dehydration of fructose, dissociate. Under the catalysis by the hydrogen ions (H+), the dehydration is started by withdrawing a water molecule from the hemiacetal at C2 of d-fructofuranose to form 2,5-anhydro-d-mannose [50]. Subsequently, two consecutive β-dehydrations in the ring result in HMF [51]. The rehydration of HMF to levulinic acid is a constant side-reaction in the process of sugar-to-HMF conversion [6,8,12]. However, levulinic acid was not detected in our catalytic system. Previous studies reported that the formation of levulinic acid requires highly acidic conditions [15,52], which suggests that EDTA, a medium acid, is not strong enough to rehydrate HMF. 3.7 Dehydration of fructose using commercially available catalysts Several other commercially available compounds were also used as the catalysts to dehydrate fructose in this biphasic system. As shown in Table 3 , the homogeneous organic acids produced a lower yield of HMF even if the higher conversion of fructose was observed (entries, 2–4). The reason for the low HMF yield under these organic acid catalysts could be attributed to their high solubility in the organic phase, which prevented them from contacting the fructose and degraded the produced HMF. HMF yields of 86 ± 4, 90 ± 3, and 89 ± 4% are achieved under the catalysis of CA, HCl, and H2SO4. However, it is difficult to recycle these catalysts because they are homogeneous. A higher HMF yield of 91 ± 4% was achieved over Amb-15, which is a widely used solid acid (entry 8). However, it suffers from higher catalyst loading and lower reusability (entry 9). Considering the catalytic and recoverable efficiency, it can be concluded that EDTA is an efficient commercially available catalyst for the production HMF from fructose. 4 Conclusions In summary, a novel catalytic system based on a widely available tetravalent organic acid EDTA was developed for the conversion of fructose to HMF. An optimal HMF yield of 89 ± 3% was achieved over EDTA in the biphasic system comprising H2O:PVP/MIBK:2-But (1.0 g:0.1 g/2.8 mL:1.2 mL). Interestingly, the EDTA catalyst showed temperature-responsive properties and could be easily recycled by cooling the reaction mixture to room temperature. The HMF yield dropped to 81 ± 2% from 89 ± 3% after being reused for five times. The catalytic ability of EDTA could be renewed after removing humins by purification by purification in NaOH/HCl, implying that the loss of activity was mainly due to the accumulation of humins. FTIR spectra of fresh and recycled EDTA (purified with NaOH/HCl) shown that the EDTA catalyst indeed maintained its chemical structure under the reaction conditions. Moreover, only 4.3 ± 0.2% of initial EDTA was leached after five rounds of recycling, which showed the high recycling capacity of this catalyst. Considering all these aspects, it can be concluded that EDTA is an efficient organic acid catalyst for the conversion of fructose to HMF and has great potential for practical applications. coredata.dc:description: The widely available reagent ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) was used as a temperature-responsive catalyst to produce 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) from fructose. Using this catalyst, a remarkable HMF yield of 89 ± 3% was achieved in a water-MIBK biphasic system containing polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and 2-butanol. The pH of the reaction system based on EDTA as a catalyst was shown to be temperature-responsive. Moreover, the EDTA catalyst could be recycled simply by cooling the reaction liquid to room temperature due to its temperature-dependent solubility in water. A slight decrease in the yield of HMF (from 89 ± 3 to 81 ± 2%) was observed after EDTA repeated use for five cycles, and a yield of 88 ± 2% was achieved again after purification of the recycled EDTA via recrystallization with NaOH/HCl. The FTIR spectrum of recycled EDTA was almost the same as that of fresh catalyst, and TG analysis showed the decomposition temperature of EDTA is about 260 °C. Furthermore, a leaching test revealed that only 4.3 ± 0.2% of the initial EDTA was lost after five-time reuse.
coredata.dc:title: Dehydration of fructose into 5-hydroxymethylfurfural in a biphasic system using EDTA as a temperature-responsive catalyst
